ygData.msgSnippet: Hola, ... Sorry, don t buy it. 1) DNS was important for sure, but not crucial to the initial success, and 2) search engines became poweful *because* of REST,

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1

Hola,

"Nina Jeliazkova" <jeliazkova.nina@...> wrote:
> Internet became massively useful after 1) distributed name resolution
> called DNS was invented and 2) search engines became powerful enough.

Sorry, don't buy it. 1) DNS was important for sure, but not crucial to the
initial success, and 2) search engines became poweful *because* of REST,
not despite it.

> > The ambiguity of REST/HTTP is exactly why it *is* so powerful as a
concept.
>
> AFAIK , REST is not defined as HTTP specific, on the contrary.

Uh, no, it's the other way around; HTTP is defined as REST. I often say
REST/HTTP because we mostly blur the lines between the two in most of these
discussions, but yes, HTTP is an implementation of a RESTful protocol.

> What I do challenge is the missing semantic level, which makes
> impossible to find out what all these resources are about.

Impossible?

> I don't
> understand what's wrong of admitting HTTP is _the_ transport level for
> myriad of specific applications, defining their own semantics in the
> HTTP message body payload.

Is anyone denying this? *puzzled*

>  Or do we perceive OSI architecture fixed
> in stone once and forever?  Sure it is in the textbooks, but not
> always as positive example. It is often cited that early in the
> Internet history, there were no precise idea what the applications
> will appear, so why we insist there could be no layer above OSI 7?

No one is denying that there is a layer above. It's just not REST, it's
something else. Currently, it's a mess, but with some good clues and a
growing best-practice, and early manifestations of specs.

What puzzles me is the insistence that this semantic layer belongs in REST.

> Comparison with WWW is not fair.  There is a single shared semantic
> for human readable web pages, and our brains (so far) are way better
> resolving the semantics, compared to software code.

As much as I'd like to agree with you, I don't. There's plenty of known and
heavvily used content types that are not meant for human digestion, such as
images, CSS and JS files, JSON, and XML and further up into abstraction.
Only the *browser* is human readable; the markup, images and code is not
(unless you're a geek).

> I do remember times when web sites were
> participating in "rings", where each site was happy to include links
> to the next one in the ring, thus allowing a new sites to become
> visible.

It was also a very early example of social engineering.

> Another way to learn about a web site was for somebody to
> share the link by email, or even offline.  The HATEOAS "follow your
> nose" approach reminds me exactly this - no global knowledge, just
> follow the next step.

There's a difference between a trail laid down in bread-crumbs, and one
that is carved in stone. "Follow-your-nose" is not the same as abandon
common knowledge. Ever written a FOAF crawler? The principle is to follow
your nose, but using an established ontology. Whether you're traversing
nodes or resources (some times orthagonal to each other) doesn't matter to
the HATEOAS concept.

> The power of Internet rose when the web of links
> started to be analysed as a whole, not just looking at the next peek.

Not sure if I can agree with this, either. Even the web crawlers are
looking for the next peek, so I don't see a sharp edge between the past and
present here.

> However, web services (not only REST) are in the pre-search era, quite
> possible due to common semantics lacking.  May be because of something
> else as well. IMHO only of course.

Big vendors and lock-in, I think. RESTful thinking has been around for a
long time, even in the pre-search era, but just like with good wine ...

> Scenarios - well, couple of, but details are not necessary in the
> scope of this thread. Basically, having number of REST services under
> common API running in several places in the world, how do you find if
> there is a specific piece of information that could be retrieved from
> any of them, or specific processing capability available?  Sure there
> are custom solutions, but from this discussion I gather a generic one
> is hardly of interest.

Well, again, it depends on what you're after. This sounds more like a
problem of persistent global identiy management more than semantics of a
specific service, but it's hard to tell without a bit more info. Feel free
to raise another thread; it's RESTful, after all.

Regards,

Alex

--0023543a279ee4cca704b5ad5d8a
